showFullCode.title: Show Complete File
showFullCode.description: Show complete file for code, with bootstrap and error handling included.

accountId.description: Long-term persistent identity of the account. Not an account number. This identity must be unique to the owning institution.

accountNumberDisplay.description: Account display number for the end user’s handle at owning institution. This is to be displayed by the Interface Provider.

lineOfBusiness.description: The line of business, such as consumer, consumer joint, small business, corporate, etc.

transferOut.description: Account is eligible for outgoing transfers

Payment%20Network%20Supported%20by%20Acc.title: Payment Network Supported by Account
Payment%20Network%20Supported%20by%20Acc.description: This provides details required to execute a transaction against the account within the payment network

bankId.description: Bank identifier used by the payment network ie. Routing Number

identifier.description: The number used to identify the account within the payment network. If identifierType is ACCOUNT_NUMBER, this is the account number.

transferIn.description: Can transfer funds to the account using this information

transferOut.description: Can transfer funds from the account using this information

Address.title: Address
Address.description: U.S. domestic address or a foreign address with country other than 'US'

region.description: State, Province, Territory, Canton or Prefecture. From [Universal Postal Union](https://www.upu.int/en/Postal-Solutions/Programmes-Services/Addressing-Solutions#addressing-s42-standard) as of 2-26-2020, [S42 International Address Standards](https://www.upu.int/UPU/media/upu/documents/PostCode/S42_International-Addressing-Standards.pdf). For U.S. addresses can be 2-character code from '#/components/schemas/StateCode'

accountId.description: Corresponds to AccountId in Account

amount.description:
The amount of money in the account currency.

If balanceType is `ASSET`:

  1. If `debitCreditMemo` = `DEBIT`, sign is "+" or not present
  2. If `CREDIT`, sign is "-"

If balanceType is `LIABILITY`:

  1. If `debitCreditMemo` = `DEBIT`, sign is "-"
  2. If `CREDIT`, sign is "+" or not present

category.description: Transaction category, preferably MCC or SIC.

imageIds.description: Array of image identifiers (unique to transaction) used to retrieve images of check or transaction receipt.

foreignAmount.description: The amount of money in the foreign currency

foreignCurrency.description: The ISO 4217 code of the foreign currency

links.description: Links (unique to this Transaction) used to retrieve images of checks or transaction receipts, or invoke other APIs

postedTimestamp.description: The date and time that the transaction was posted to the account. If not provided then TransactionTimestamp can be used as PostedTimeStamp.

referenceTransactionId.description:
Akoya ensures that this field is populated for all transactions which are reversals, otherwise it is null. Either way it is always present.

For reverse postings, the identity of the transaction being reversed. For the correction transaction, the identity of the reversing post. For credit card posting transactions, the identity of the authorization transaction.

transactionId.description:
Long term persistent identity of the transaction (unique to account). 
Transaction IDs should: 

  1. be the same for pending and posted 
  2. be different for reversed transactions 
  3. `referenceTransactionId` should be present for reversed transactions'

transactionTimestamp.description:
The date and time that the transaction was added to the server backend systems.

Akoya ensures that this field is populated for all transactions to which it applies, otherwise it is null. Either way it is always present.

Date%20and%20Amount.description: Date, description, and amount. When used in 1098-Q, description is optional

date.description: Date of amount. When used in 1098-Q, date of last payment in month

description.description: Description of amount. When used in 1098-Q, may use MonthAbbreviation

amount.description: Amount of payment or receipt. When used in 1098-Q, monthly total

vestings.description: An array of equityGrant vestings. Provides the past, present, and future vesting schedule and percentages.

Error.title: Error
Error.description: An error entity which can be used at the API level for error responses or at the account level to indicate a problem specific to a particular account. See the error codes and descriptions defined in the latest FDX API Specification document, section 6.2 Errors

code.description: Error code defined by FDX API Specification or Data Provider indicating the error situation which has occurred

message.description: End user displayable information which might help the customer diagnose an error

debugMessage.description: Message used to debug the root cause of the error. Contents should not be used in consumer's business logic. Can change at any time and should only be used for consumer to communicate with the data provider about an issue. Provider can include an error GUID in message for their use.

Form%201042-S%20Agent.title: Form 1042-S Agent
Form%201042-S%20Agent.description:
One of various persons or businesses involved in Form 1042-S reporting. Use
  * `tin` for
    * Box 12a, Withholding Agent EIN,
    * Box 13e, Recipient U.S. TIN,
    * Box 14b, Primary Withholding Agent EIN,
    * Box 15a, Intermediary or flow-through entity EIN,
    * Box 16b, Payer TIN
  * `individualName` or `businessName` for
    * Box 12d, Withholding Agent name,
    * Box 13a, Recipient name,
    * Box 14a, Primary Withholding Agent name,
    * Box 15d, Intermediary or flow-through entity name,
    * Box 16a, Payer name
  * `address.country` for
    * Box 12f, Withholding Agent Country code,
    * Box 13b, Recipient Country code,
    * Box 15f, Intermediary or flow-through entity Country code
  * `address` for
    * Boxes 12h-i, Withholding Agent Address,
    * Boxes 13c-d, Recipient Address,
    * Boxes 15h-i, Intermediary or flow-through entity Address

calendarYearFor401K.description: Date for this calendar year for 401K account

employerName.description: Name of the employer in investment 401k Plan

availableCashBalance.description: Cash balance across all sub-accounts. Should include sweep funds.

balanceList.description: Balance List. Name value pair aggregate.

currentValue.description: Total current value of all investments

contribution.description: Array of contribution objects. Describes how new contributions are distributed among the available securities

vesting.description: Array of vesting objects. Provides the past, present, and future vesting schedule and percentages

equityGrants.description: Provides equity grant information on Restricted Stock Units, Restricted Stock Awards, Stock Appreciation Right, Stock Options, Performance Awards, and Total Share Return Units

accountId.description: Corresponds to AccountId in Account

amount.description:
The amount of money in the account currency.

If balanceType is `ASSET`:

  1. If `debitCreditMemo` = `DEBIT`, sign is "+" or not present
  2. If `CREDIT`, sign is "-"

If balanceType is `LIABILITY`:

  1. If `debitCreditMemo` = `DEBIT`, sign is "-"
  2. If `CREDIT`, sign is "+" or not present

category.description: Transaction category, preferably MCC or SIC.

imageIds.description: Array of image identifiers (unique to transaction) used to retrieve images of check or transaction receipt.

foreignAmount.description: The amount of money in the foreign currency

foreignCurrency.description: The ISO 4217 code of the foreign currency

links.description: Links (unique to this Transaction) used to retrieve images of checks or transaction receipts, or invoke other APIs

postedTimestamp.description: The date and time that the transaction was posted to the account. If not provided then TransactionTimestamp can be used as PostedTimeStamp.

referenceTransactionId.description:
Akoya ensures that this field is populated for all transactions which are reversals, otherwise it is null. Either way it is always present.

For reverse postings, the identity of the transaction being reversed. For the correction transaction, the identity of the reversing post. For credit card posting transactions, the identity of the authorization transaction.

transactionId.description:
Long term persistent identity of the transaction (unique to account). 
Transaction IDs should: 

  1. be the same for pending and posted 
  2. be different for reversed transactions 
  3. `referenceTransactionId` should be present for reversed transactions'

transactionTimestamp.description:
The date and time that the transaction was added to the server backend systems.

Akoya ensures that this field is populated for all transactions to which it applies, otherwise it is null. Either way it is always present.

fractionalCash.description: Cash for fractional units (used for stock splits).

loanId.description: For 401k accounts only. This indicates the transaction was due to a loan or a loan repayment.

loanInterest.description: How much loan pre-payment is interest.

loanPrincipal.description: How much loan pre-payment is principal.

markup.description: Portion of unit price that is attributed to the dealer markup.

payrollDate.description: The date for the 401k transaction was obtained in payroll.

penalty.description: Indicates amount withheld due to a penalty.

priorYearContrib.description: Indicates this buy was made using prior years contribution. TRUE or FALSE.

shares.description: Number of shares (with decimals). Negative numbers indicate securities are being removed from the account.

unitPrice.description: Price per commonly-quoted unit. Does not include markup/markdown, unitprice. Share price for stocks, mutual funds, and others. Percentage of par for bonds. Per share (not contract) for options.

units.description: For security-based actions other than stock splits, quantity. Shares for stocks, mutual funds, and others. Face value for bonds. Contracts for options.

State%20Code.title: State Code
State%20Code.description:
The codes for U.S. states, possessions and military overseas addresses. From [USPS Publication 28 - Postal Addressing Standards](https://pe.usps.com/text/pub28/28apb.htm) and [IRS Zip Code and State Abbreviations](https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-utl/zip_code_and_state_abbreviations.pdf). Includes codes for 50 states and District of Columbia plus:
  * AA - Armed Forces Americas (except Canada)
  * AE - Armed Forces Europe, Africa, the Middle East, and Canada
  * AP - Armed Forces Pacific
  * AS - American Samoa
  * FM - Federated States of Micronesia
  * GU - Guam
  * MH - Marshall Islands
  * MP - Northern Mariana Islands
  * PR - Puerto Rico
  * PW - Palau
  * VI - U.S. Virgin Islands

Title: Getting Started with Akoya APIs v2.4.0

Nodes.Text: Akoya product APIs provide secure data access. By default, servers are set for the **Akoya sandbox environment**.
- Added **Tax** product

- Removed erroneous `accountId` query param from **Taxlots** endpoint
- Added **TaxLots** endpoint

- Added `mode` query parameter to **Account Information**, **Balances**, **Investments**, and **Transactions** to support standard mode
- Edited callouts for **Account Holder** endpoint

- Fixed typo in `accountIds` query parameter for `/accounts-info`, `/balances`, `/accounts`
- Added security method for **Account Holder Information** to bearer token (previously defaulted to basic auth)
- Added examples and descriptions to some schemas
- Added HTTP status **429 FDX error 1207**

- Added optional `x-akoya-interaction-type` header to all endpoints to specify if a request is part of a batch process
- Updated tags to organize endpoints by Akoya product
- Added **206 response** to `/accounts-info`, `/balances`, `/accounts`

- Introduced **Statements** product
- Updated **Customers** product with additional endpoint: **Account Holder Information**

- Launch of Akoya products:
  - **Account Info**
  - **Balances**
  - **Investments**
  - **Transactions**
  - **Payments**
  - **Customers**
The Akoya API supports multiple environments. Each environment includes one or more **base URIs** to use for product and authentication requests.
**Sandbox server**

| Server       | Base URI                                    |
|--------------|---------------------------------------------|
| default      | `https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com`    |
| auth server  | `https://sandbox-idp.ddp.akoya.com`         |
**Products server**

| Server       | Base URI                                 |
|--------------|------------------------------------------|
| default      | `https://products.ddp.akoya.com`         |
| auth server  | `https://sandbox-idp.ddp.akoya.com`      |

- **Default environment** → Production
- **Default server** → Default
This API supports the following authentication schemes:

- **basicAuth** (Basic Authentication)
- **bearerAuth** (OAuth 2 Bearer Token)
- **acgAuth** (OAuth 2 Authorization Code Grant)
HTTP Basic Authentication requires **client credentials**. The client credentials are concatenated with a colon (`:`) and Base64-encoded before being sent in the **Authorization** header.
**Example:**

curl {BASEURI} -u '{USERNAME}:{PASSWORD}'
GET / HTTP/1.1
Host: {HOST}
Authorization: Basic dXNlcm5hbWU6cGFzc3dvcmQ=
The **bearer token** is sent in the request like this:
Documentation for accessing and setting credentials for acgAuth.

| Name              | Type               | Description                                           |
|-------------------|--------------------|-------------------------------------------------------|
| OAuthClientId     | String             | OAuth 2 Client ID                                    |
| OAuthClientSecret | String             | OAuth 2 Client Secret                                |
| OAuthRedirectUri  | String             | OAuth 2 Redirection endpoint or Callback URI         |
| OAuthScopes       | OAuthScopeAcgAuth  | List of scopes that apply to the OAuth token         |

Nodes.Title: Steps for Authorization Code Grant Flow

Nodes.Text: Redirect the user to the authorization page with initialized scopes:
{URI for auth server}/?response_type=code&client_id={CLIENT_ID}&redirect_uri={REDIRECT_URI}&scope={SCOPE}

- If approved, an authorization code is sent:  
  https://example.com/oauth/callback?code=XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

- If denied, an error is returned:  
  https://example.com/oauth/callback?error=access_denied
Exchange the authorization code for an access token:

curl -X POST
--url '{URI for auth server}/token'
--user '{CLIENT_ID}:{CLIENT_SECRET}'
--header 'Accept: application/json'
--data 'grant_type=authorization_code'
--data 'code={CODE}'
--data 'redirect_uri={REDIRECT_URI}'

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: Steps for Authorization Code Grant Flow

Nodes.Text: Scopes allow your application to only request the resources it needs.

| Scope Name      | Description                                 |
|-----------------|---------------------------------------------|
| openid          | OpenID Connect authentication              |
| profile         | Access to user profile information          |
| offline_access  | Request refresh tokens for offline access   |
Access tokens may expire. You can use the refresh token to obtain a new access token:

curl -X POST
--url '{URI for auth server}/token'
--user '{CLIENT_ID}:{CLIENT_SECRET}'
--header 'Accept: application/json'
--data 'grant_type=refresh_token'
--data 'refresh_token={REFRESH_TOKEN}'
-d 'scope={OPTIONAL_SCOPE}'
- Added `taxlots` endpoint to the **Investments** product.
- Enhanced description text for the **Customer Info** and **Account Holder Information** endpoints.
- Added `mode` query parameter to **Account Information**, **Balances**, **Investments**, and **Transactions** to support standard mode.

- Fixed typo in `accountIds` query parameter for `/accounts-info`, `/balances`, `/accounts`.
- Added security method for **Account Holder Information** to bearer token (missing method defaulted to basic auth).
- Added examples and descriptions to some schemas.
- Added HTTP status **429** FDX error **1207**.

- Added optional `x-akoya-interaction-type` header to all endpoints to specify if a request is part of a batch process.
- OpenAPI spec update of tags to organize endpoints by Akoya product.
- **206 response** added to `/accounts-info`, `/balances`, `/accounts`.
- New **Statements** product and **Customers** product updated with additional endpoint, **Account Holder Information**.
- Launch of Akoya products: **Account Info**, **Balances**, **Investments**, **Transactions**, **Payments**, **Customers**.
- Added 400 level responses.
- Updated response payload.

- Added sandbox server.
- Added notification banners.

- Added a request body to the **Get Consent Grant** endpoint.
- Corrected description text for the **Get Consent Grant** endpoint.
- Updated response payload for **Send sandbox test event**.

- Added sandbox API server.
- Added sandbox test event endpoint.

- **Create App** endpoint: Specify that the scope must include at least one product in addition to Account Information.
- **Get Subscriptions for App** endpoint: Mention that if an app is created with only Account Information, no subscriptions will be returned for that app.
- Initial release.

- Updated scope values to use `app_management_v2` for **Apps Management API** in the wake of the v1 deprecation.  
  Added callout for the same.

- Added scope for the **Consent notifications API**: `scope=notifications_subscriptions` advisory.
- Added a callout explaining the difference in scope for the Management and Notifications APIs.
- Added descriptive text announcing deprecation of v1.

- Updated description for the **Akoya providers by product** endpoint:
  - Corrected query examples.

Akoya product APIs for data access. Default servers are set for the Akoya sandbox environment.
Akoya APIs include the following updates:

- v2.4.0
  - Added Tax product
- v2.3.0
  - Removed erroneous `accountId` query param from Taxlots endpoint
  - Added TaxLots endpoint
- v2.2.2
  - Added mode query parameter to Account Information, Balances, Investments, and Transactions to support standard mode.
  - Edited callouts for Account Holder endpoint
- v2.2.1
  - Fixed typo in `accountIds` query parameter for `/accounts-info`, `/balances`, `/accounts`
  - Added security method for `Account holder information` to bear token. Missing method defaulted to basic auth.
  - Added examples and descriptions to some schemas
  - Added HTTP status `429` FDX error `1207`.
- v2.2 Additions
  - Added optional `x-akoya-interaction-type` header to all endpoints to specify if a request is part of a batch process
  - Update of tags to organize endpoints by Akoya product
  - `206` response added to `/accounts-info`, `/balances`, `/accounts`
- v2.1 New Statements product and Customers product updated with additional endpoint, `Account holder information`.
- v2.0 Launch of Akoya products: Account Info, Balances, Investments, Transactions, Payments, Customers.

You must have Python ```3.7+``` installed on your system to install and run this SDK. This SDK package depends on other Python packages like pytest, etc. These dependencies are defined in the ```requirements.txt``` file that comes with the SDK. To resolve these dependencies, you can use the PIP Dependency manager. Install it by following steps at [https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/installing/](https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/installing/).

Python and PIP executables should be defined in your PATH. Open command prompt and type ```pip --version```. This should display the version of the PIP Dependency Manager installed if your installation was successful and the paths are properly defined.

* Using command line, navigate to the directory containing the generated files (including ```requirements.txt```) for the SDK.
* Run the command ```pip install -r requirements.txt```. This should install all the required dependencies.
The following section explains how to use the akoyaapisv240 library in a new project.
Open up a Python IDE like PyCharm. The basic workflow presented here is also applicable if you prefer using a different editor or IDE.
Click on `Open` in PyCharm to browse to your generated SDK directory and then click `OK`.
The project files will be displayed in the side bar as follows:
Create a new directory by right clicking on the solution name as shown below:

Nodes.Text: After this you can write code to instantiate an API client object, get a controller object and  make API calls. Sample code is given in the subsequent sections.
To run the file within your test project, right click on your Python file inside your Test project and click on `Run`
The SDK can be configured to use a different environment for making API calls. Available environments are:
Fields
The following parameters are configurable for the API Client:

Data: The Http Client passed from the sdk user for making requests
The value which determines to override properties of the passed Http Client from the sdk user
The callback value that is invoked before and after an HTTP call is made to an endpoint

The value to use for connection timeout.
**Default: 30**

The number of times to retry an endpoint call if it fails.
**Default: 0**

A backoff factor to apply between attempts after the second try.
**Default: 2**

The http methods on which retry is to be done.
**Default: ['GET', 'PUT', 'GET', 'PUT']**
Optional proxy configuration to route HTTP requests through a proxy server.
The SDK logging configuration for API calls
The credential object for Basic Authentication
The credential object for OAuth 2 Bearer token
The credential object for OAuth 2 Authorization Code Grant

Nodes.Text: The API client can be initialized as follows:

import logging

from akoyaapisv240.akoyaapisv_240_client import Akoyaapisv240Client
from akoyaapisv240.configuration import Environment
from akoyaapisv240.http.auth.acg_auth import AcgAuthCredentials
from akoyaapisv240.http.auth.basic_auth import BasicAuthCredentials
from akoyaapisv240.http.auth.bearer_auth import BearerAuthCredentials
from akoyaapisv240.logging.configuration.api_logging_configuration import LoggingConfiguration
from akoyaapisv240.logging.configuration.api_logging_configuration import RequestLoggingConfiguration
from akoyaapisv240.logging.configuration.api_logging_configuration import ResponseLoggingConfiguration
from akoyaapisv240.models.oauth_scope_acg_auth import OauthScopeAcgAuth

client = Akoyaapisv240Client(
    basic_auth_credentials=BasicAuthCredentials(
        username='Username',
        password='Password'
    ),
    bearer_auth_credentials=BearerAuthCredentials(
        access_token='AccessToken'
    ),
    acg_auth_credentials=AcgAuthCredentials(
        oauth_client_id='OAuthClientId',
        oauth_client_secret='OAuthClientSecret',
        oauth_redirect_uri='OAuthRedirectUri',
        oauth_scopes=[
            OauthScopeAcgAuth.OPENID,
            OauthScopeAcgAuth.PROFILE
        ]
    ),
    environment=Environment.PRODUCTION,
    logging_configuration=LoggingConfiguration(
        log_level=logging.INFO,
        request_logging_config=RequestLoggingConfiguration(
            log_body=True
        ),
        response_logging_config=ResponseLoggingConfiguration(
            log_headers=True
        )
    )
)

This API uses the following authentication schemes.
* [`basicAuth (Basic Authentication)`]($h/__auth_BasicAuth)
* [`bearerAuth (OAuth 2 Bearer token)`]($h/__auth_BearerAuth)
* [`acgAuth (OAuth 2 Authorization Code Grant)`]($h/__auth_AcgAuth)
Documentation for accessing and setting credentials for basicAuth.

Data: The username to use with basic authentication
The password to use with basic authentication

Nodes.Text: **Note:** Auth credentials can be set using `BasicAuthCredentials` object, passed in as named parameter `basic_auth_credentials` in the client initialization.
You must provide credentials in the client as shown in the following code snippet.

from akoyaapisv240.akoyaapisv_240_client import Akoyaapisv240Client
from akoyaapisv240.http.auth.basic_auth import BasicAuthCredentials

client = Akoyaapisv240Client(
    basic_auth_credentials=BasicAuthCredentials(
        username='Username',
        password='Password'
    )
)
Documentation for accessing and setting credentials for bearerAuth.

Data: The OAuth 2.0 Access Token to use for API requests.

Nodes.Text: **Note:** Auth credentials can be set using `BearerAuthCredentials` object, passed in as named parameter `bearer_auth_credentials` in the client initialization.
You must provide credentials in the client as shown in the following code snippet.

from akoyaapisv240.akoyaapisv_240_client import Akoyaapisv240Client
from akoyaapisv240.http.auth.bearer_auth import BearerAuthCredentials

client = Akoyaapisv240Client(
    bearer_auth_credentials=BearerAuthCredentials(
        access_token='AccessToken'
    )
)
Documentation for accessing and setting credentials for acgAuth.

Data: OAuth 2 Redirection endpoint or Callback Uri
Object for storing information about the OAuth token
List of scopes that apply to the OAuth token

Nodes.Text: **Note:** Auth credentials can be set using `AcgAuthCredentials` object, passed in as named parameter `acg_auth_credentials` in the client initialization.
You must initialize the client with *OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Grant* credentials as shown in the following code snippet.

from akoyaapisv240.akoyaapisv_240_client import Akoyaapisv240Client
from akoyaapisv240.http.auth.acg_auth import AcgAuthCredentials
from akoyaapisv240.models.oauth_scope_acg_auth import OauthScopeAcgAuth

client = Akoyaapisv240Client(
    acg_auth_credentials=AcgAuthCredentials(
        oauth_client_id='OAuthClientId',
        oauth_client_secret='OAuthClientSecret',
        oauth_redirect_uri='OAuthRedirectUri',
        oauth_scopes=[
            OauthScopeAcgAuth.OPENID,
            OauthScopeAcgAuth.PROFILE
        ]
    )
)

Your application must obtain user authorization before it can execute an endpoint call in case this SDK chooses to use *OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Grant*. This authorization includes the following steps

To obtain user's consent, you must redirect the user to the authorization page.The `get_authorization_url()` method creates the URL to the authorization page. You must have initialized the client with scopes for which you need permission to access.
auth_url = client.acg_auth.get_authorization_url()
Once the user responds to the consent request, the OAuth 2.0 server responds to your application's access request by redirecting the user to the redirect URI specified set in `Configuration`.
If the user approves the request, the authorization code will be sent as the `code` query string:
https://example.com/oauth/callback?code=XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
If the user does not approve the request, the response contains an `error` query string:
https://example.com/oauth/callback?error=access_denied
After the server receives the code, it can exchange this for an *access token*. The access token is an object containing information for authorizing client requests and refreshing the token itself.

try:
    token = client.acg_auth.fetch_token('code')
    acg_auth_credentials = client.config.acg_auth_credentials.clone_with(oauth_token=token)
    config = client.config.clone_with(acg_auth_credentials=acg_auth_credentials)
    client = Akoyaapisv240Client(config=config)
except OauthProviderException as ex:
    # handle exception
    pass
except ApiException as ex:
    # handle exception
    pass

Steps.Title: 4\. Authorize the client using the code

Nodes.Text: Scopes enable your application to only request access to the resources it needs while enabling users to control the amount of access they grant to your application. Available scopes are defined in the [`OauthScopeAcgAuth`]($m/OAuth%20ScopeAcgAuth) enumeration.

Data: Request refresh tokens for offline access

Nodes.Text: An access token may expire after sometime. To extend its lifetime, you must refresh the token.
If a token expires, an exception will be thrown before the next endpoint call requiring authentication.
It is recommended that you store the access token for reuse.

# store token
save_token_to_database(client.config.acg_auth_credentials.oauth_token)

Steps.Title: Storing an access token for reuse

Nodes.Text: To authorize a client using a stored access token, just set the access token in Configuration along with the other configuration parameters before creating the client:

Steps.Title: Creating a client from a stored token

Nodes.Text:
from akoyaapisv240.akoyaapisv_240_client import Akoyaapisv240Client
from akoyaapisv240.http.auth.acg_auth import AcgAuthCredentials
from akoyaapisv240.models.oauth_scope_acg_auth import OauthScopeAcgAuth
from akoyaapisv240.exceptions.oauth_provider_exception import OauthProviderException

client = Akoyaapisv240Client(
    acg_auth_credentials=AcgAuthCredentials(
        oauth_client_id='OAuthClientId',
        oauth_client_secret='OAuthClientSecret',
        oauth_redirect_uri='OAuthRedirectUri',
        oauth_scopes=[
            OauthScopeAcgAuth.OPENID,
            OauthScopeAcgAuth.PROFILE
        ]
    )
)
# function for storing token to database
def save_token_to_database(token):
    # code to save the token to database
    pass

# function for loading token from database
def load_token_from_database():
    # load token from database and return it (return None if no token exists)
    pass

# obtain access token, needed for client to be authorized
previous_token = load_token_from_database()
if previous_token:
    # restore previous access token
    acg_auth_credentials = client.config.acg_auth_credentials.clone_with(oauth_token=previous_token)
    config = client.config.clone_with(acg_auth_credentials=acg_auth_credentials)
    client = Akoyaapisv240Client(config=config)
else:
    # redirect user to a page that handles authorization
    pass

# the client is now authorized and you can use controllers to make endpoint calls

Nodes.Title: Introduction to the Data Access Network

Nodes.Text: Akoya enables consumers to provide third-party access to their financial data in a safe, secure, and transparent way.
![Diagram of Akoya Data Access Network](static\images\guides\introduction\akoya-data-access-networl.png)

The Akoya mission is to create trust among financial institutions, fintechs, and data aggregators to ensure mass participation in Open Finance. Akoya secures the way consumers provide access to their data with increased security, privacy, and control over their information by transitioning data aggregation toward application programming interface (API)–based data access.

- Removes login credentials from data sharing by implementing tokenized access.
- Facilitates a consent flow that enables customers to share their accounts and permission data directly from their data provider.
- Ensures consumers have control through the ability to monitor and disable access.

- Does not store any data accessed or shared on its network.
- Maintains a pass-through model to promote privacy for all consumers.
- Akoya does not pick favorites, nor hide providers. Akoya does not know who the consumer is or what data they are sharing.

- Akoya serves as a data-access network, not a data-aggregation service.
- Akoya delivers tokenized credentials used between a financial data provider and a financial app.
- Akoya does not open the package, inspect it, and repackage it as legacy aggregators do.
- Instead, Akoya simply gifts the package safely from point A to point B.

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: Introduction to the Data Access Network

Nodes.Text: The consent flow enables a customer to authenticate, select accounts, and permission data to flow from their data provider through the Data Access Network out to a third-party fintech app. This keeps your customers’ login credentials from being shared with third parties.
*Tip: You may click on images to view in full screen*
![Consent Flow Screenshots](static\images\guides\introduction\consentFlow.png)
**Steps:**

1. Emily wants to connect a fintech app to her financial institution accounts, in this example, at her fictional bank, Mikomo.
2. Emily is redirected by the fintech app to Akoya where the fintech and Mikomo site are validated.
3. Akoya retrieves an auth grant code to Mikomo Bank and Emily authenticates at the Mikomo Bank site.
4. Emily agrees to terms and conditions and gives authorization to provide access of her data to her fintech app.
5. Mikomo Bank issues an authorization grant code to Akoya who in turn requests the Mikomo Bank token.
6. Using Mikomo Bank’s token, Akoya requests Emily’s account list for selection and permissioning to her fintech app. Emily approves account selection.
7. Akoya redirects Emily back to her fintech app with the Akoya auth code.
8. The Akoya auth code is exchanged by the fintech app for an Akoya ID token. The fintech app uses the Akoya token to request Emily’s account details. Akoya uses the Mikomo Bank’s token to request permissioned details.
9. Mikomo Bank returns data to Akoya. Akoya gets the entitlements policy and applies Mikomo Bank’s rules. Akoya then returns the data to the fintech app.
10. Emily sees the permissioned account data.
![Akoya API v2 Example](static\images\guides\introduction\akoya-api-v2.png)
Based on Financial Data Exchange (FDX) specifications, the **Akoya API v2** allows recipients to request consumer-permissioned data to flow from a provider through the Data Access Network.

Through data mapping and API integration, Akoya translates responses from providers—even those with proprietary APIs—into a common format. Expected and standard API responses help mitigate the need for proprietary APIs, thereby reducing development costs.
![Connection Management Diagram](static\images\guides\introduction\connectionManagement.png)
The **Management Console** is available for data providers to self-manage their connections and configure their settings in the Akoya Data Access Network.
Akoya also provides aggregators and fintechs with the **Data Recipient Hub** to manage their connection to providers.
The Akoya Permission API is used by a data provider to add support to their customer experience for Akoya account permission management.

By making calls to the API, a provider can add a permission dashboard that allows their consumers to see which recipients have access to their permissioned data, add or remove accounts, or remove access overall.

- **FDX** is the primary API interface for data recipients. All APIs are REST.
- **OIDC, OAuth 2.0, and JWT** implemented for authorization and authentication.
- Full monitoring, auditability, and traceability.
- Different logging capabilities available.
- Cloud-native implementation on **AWS** that enables scaling in real-time.
- Akoya’s cloud implementation enables continuous application upgrades across the network.
- Strong in-flight and at-rest encryption.
- Least Privilege Zero-Trust Model.
- Secure application development implemented by **SOC2**.
- **NIST** and FFIEC frameworks leveraged to define and prioritize security controls.
- Akoya is **SOC 2 Type 2** certified.

Nodes.Title: Introduction to Mikomo and the Sandbox

Nodes.Text: We want you to be able to learn our platform and test our APIs in a safe environment with test data, so we created **Mikomo Bank** and a set of test API servers for your use.
Mikomo is a mock data provider managed by Akoya. It contains a number of test user accounts whose response payloads resemble many of the providers on our network.
You can use these accounts to:

- Step through the consent process.
- Retrieve test data.
Since the exact responses vary by provider, you can use specific test accounts to simulate receiving data from that provider.
The **sandbox** is a set of test API servers you can use to make calls in a non-production setting.

- You can **ONLY** use our mock provider **Mikomo Bank** with these servers.
- All our API products are configured to use them.
- Our [Akoya API servers](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/akoya-api-servers#sandbox) doc provides a list of these test servers.

Nodes.Title: How do I get started with the sandbox?

Nodes.Text:
1. Log into the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login).
2. Go to **My apps** and create a **sandbox app**.
   - Creating a sandbox app registers a redirect URI with us and generates your API credentials.
   - If you don’t have a redirect URI yet, a placeholder redirect URI will populate automatically:
     ```
     https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/flow/callback
     ```
     
     You can use this for testing.
3. To make a sandbox API call, ensure you’re using the appropriate sandbox server base URL with our endpoints, for example:
   - `https://sandbox-idp.ddp.akoya.com/token`
   - `https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/accounts-info/{version}/{providerId}`

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: How do I get started with the sandbox?

Nodes.Text: Check out our [Getting started guide](page:getting-started/introduction), where you will step through the entire process of obtaining data using our test API servers.

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: Introduction to Mikomo and the Sandbox

Nodes.Text: Tips for integrating your application with the Akoya Data Access Network.
We have a number of implementation requirements to ensure the security of our network and your end-users' financial data.
> 🚧 **Please review these requirements before continuing!**

Nodes.Title: A consent UX in your app

Nodes.Text: Your end-user should consent to the access and use of their data from the original data provider. The Akoya consent flow leverages [OAuth 2.0 authorization](https://oauth.net/2/). For more information, see:

- [Authorization request](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.1)
- [Authorization code grant type](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-1.3.1)
- [Refresh token grant type](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-1.5)

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: A consent UX in your app

Nodes.Title: [OIDC](https://openid.net/developers/how-connect-works/) token use with secure, encrypted storage
Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: [OIDC](https://openid.net/developers/how-connect-works/) token use with secure, encrypted storage

Nodes.Text: The callback resource in your application where Akoya will send the end-user and authorization code after successful authentication.
Your app must securely store:

- `client_id`
- `client_secret`
- All tokens
⚠️ The `client_secret` should **NEVER** be hard-coded into your application's source code.

- Your company should maintain [one Data Recipient Hub team account](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/data-recipient-hub-user-manual#team-management).
- The first team member to join the Hub should send invitations to the remaining members of the team.
- See: *Data Recipient Hub v5*.
- Provide a link for the end-user to revoke permission for use of their provider's accounts.
- Build a pagination component into your app, allowing it to receive one page at a time.

- Adhere to implementation differences required by some data providers.
- These guidelines, and other integration considerations, are documented by provider in the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login).

- When major service disruptions occur that impact the network (e.g., invalidating all tokens or forcing re-authentication), please notify Akoya.
- To notify Akoya, sign into the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login) and visit the [Support Center](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/hub-manual-support-tickets#create-a-support-ticket).

- For **500-level HTTP errors**, we recommend implementing **three (3) retries** to help your app deal with short-lived, transient failures.
- The waiting time between retries should increase **exponentially** with each retry attempt.

- Akoya limits breaking changes to **major API versions**.
- Minor updates are **non-breaking, backward-compatible improvements** and are released continually.
- When migrating to Akoya API v2, plan for minor version updates and implement in a way that supports non-breaking changes.
- See: [Versioning](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/versioning).

- Send the `x-akoya-interaction-type` header with all Akoya product calls to indicate if the request is part of a batch process or a real-time, end-user interaction.
- When using a batch or bulk process, implement your app to handle **HTTP status 429, error code 1207**. If receiving this response, send bulk requests at a slower rate.

- Track the header `x-akoya-interaction-id` returned with each Akoya API request.
- Your app should handle **206 HTTP Partial Responses**.

Akoya API v2 is based on **Financial Data Exchange (FDX)** specifications (learn more about FDX [here](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/intro-to-fdx)). The following FDX guidance is recommended while using Akoya API v2:

- Utilize the FDX API, security, and user experience specifications.
- Follow FDX version recommendations for API deprecation.
- Recipients need not be members of FDX to integrate with the Akoya Data Access Network.
- FDX provides:
  - A variety of membership options.
  - Fee-free access to API specifications by accepting the intellectual property agreement.
An overview of technical implementation steps to integrate with the Akoya Data Access Network.
The following steps will guide you through creation of a test app in the Akoya sandbox.

| Task | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **Review technical requirements.** | See: [Requirements](page:guides/requirements). |
| **Register with Akoya for sandbox access.** | To register, you must provide Akoya with a redirect URI for your sandbox test app. Akoya will provide you with a **client_id** and **client_secret** for your app. |
| **Securely store client_id and secret.** | Every app has a unique client Id and secret. They must be treated as secure information and stored securely. |
| **UX – Provider popup or redirect.** | Integrate into your existing provider selection UI or build popup/redirect flows for the consumer to select the data provider(s) they'd like to connect with your app. Upon consumer selection, initiate consent and authentication via Akoya to the provider. See: [Native app integrations](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/native-app-integrations). |
| **Use sandbox data for implementation and testing.** | The Akoya sandbox includes a mock data provider (**Mikomo Financial**) with several test users that may be used for end-to-end implementation and testing. Use these test accounts for the remaining implementation steps. See: [Introduction to Sandbox](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/mikomo). |
| **Authorization grant.** | After authentication and authorization, Akoya will return the consumer to your redirect URI with an authorization grant code in the URL with the parameter `code=`. Use this authorization code to request a set of tokens for this consumer. See: [Authorization Code]($e/Account%20information/get-accounts-info). |
| **Store x-akoya-interaction-id.** | Akoya returns an interaction id in every response header. Retain the id with logs for support and error tracking. |
| **Id and refresh token generation.** | Exchange authorization code for ID and refresh token. See: [Token API reference](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/get-token) and the [token explainer](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/token-flow). |
| **Store token.** | Use your current secure token storage or implement a way to store each consumer's unique tokens. |
| **Token revocation.** | Implement a way for the consumer to remove access to their data provider account(s). See: [Revoke Token](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/revoke-token). |
| **Error cases.** | Code for authorization or token errors. Develop UX for errors, timeouts, and reauthentication. See: [Authentication errors](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/authentication-errors) and [Token API errors](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/token-errors). |
| **Validate authentication.** | Validate UX for account selection, consent, ID/refresh token for new and existing users. |

| Task | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **Store x-akoya-interaction-id.** | Akoya returns an interaction id in every response header. Retain the id with logs for support and error tracking. |
| **Accounts.** | Using the `id_token` retrieved in the Id and refresh token step above for a test user, make a call for data. See: [API Docs – Accounts info reference]($e/Account%20information/get-accounts-info). |
| **Transactions.** | Using the `id_token` retrieved in the Id and refresh token step above for a test user and the account Id retrieved in the Accounts step above, make a call for transaction data. See: [Akoya API v2 – Transactions reference]($e/Transactions/get-transactions). |
| **Error cases.** | Code for Akoya API v2 errors. Develop UX for errors, timeouts, and reauthentication. See: [Errors](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/errors). |
| **Validate data.** | Validate use and display of data in your own systems and UI. |
How to work with Akoya

Below is a list of suggested resources as you prepare to integrate with us. Ensure you’ve set up an account in the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login) (if your company already has an account, ask a team member with admin access to [add you](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/hub-manual-team-management#adding-users)) and go through the [Getting started guide](page:getting-started/introduction) before reviewing the content below.
Please learn about Akoya’s product offerings and technical requirements before starting development work.

Most reference documentation is searchable by topic on our docs site. Some content, such as provider-specific nuances or troubleshooting guides, are available in the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login).
Check out the **Data provider** and **Support Center** sections.
To help with integration, our [Postman collections](https://www.postman.com/akoya-dan/akoya-api/overview) or [OpenAPI specifications](https://docs.akoya.com/docs/openapi) may help you get started.

Nodes.Text: You should have:

- Completed testing in our **sandbox**
- Requested **production access** (from within the Hub)
When dealing with large sets of data, receiving results in segments can help apps process information in a more structured way. This retrieval of data, a page at a time, is called **pagination**.
The **`/transactions`** endpoint standardizes on **link-based pagination** with Akoya API v2.
Consider the following when implementing link-based pagination.
When making an initial transaction call, create the request with the following parameters. The result of that first request will return **links** to use for paging.
These parameters should only be used in constructing the **first transaction call**. After the first call, requesting pages must be done with links provided in results.
Some data providers may not support `offset` or `limit`. Check the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login) for provider-specific pagination support.

- **offset** – The number of items to skip before the first in the response
- **limit** – The maximum number of items to be returned in the response
- **startTime** – ISO 8601 date format in UTC (e.g., `2020-03-30T04:00:00Z`)
- **endTime** – ISO 8601 date format in UTC (e.g., `2021-03-30T04:00:00Z`)
**Note:** When using Akoya’s link-based pagination, we recommend **omitting `offset`** in the initial call.
**Parameters:**

- `providerId = mikomo`
- `accountId = g833202fb0866d0ad83472c429`
- `limit = 5`
- `startTime = 2019-02-26T00:00:00Z`
- `endTime = 2021-02-26T00:00:00Z`
**cURL:**

curl --location --request GET 'https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/transactions/v2/mikomo/g833202fb0866d0ad83472c429?startTime=2019-02-26T00:00:00Z&endTime=2021-02-26T00:00:00Z&limit=5' \
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer {{idToken}}'

The value of links.next.href may contain the offset, limit, startTime, and endTime parameters.
**Do not change these values — use the link as provided**.
If all data can be returned without paging, links.next.href will be empty.
**Example with sandbox user mikomo_10, accountId = "5426873":**

Use the links.next.href value in the first response payload to construct the next call.
**Do not change the link.** Editing offset, startTime, endTime, or limit in the provided link may cause errors or missing data.
Use links.next.href directly:

curl --location --request GET 'https://{access_url}{{links.next.href}}' \
--header 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer {{idToken}}'

Most pagination responses include links.prev.href to page back.
Some providers do not support prev. If prev is not supported and your app requires it, store the next links as the user pages.
Continue making requests using the provided links until next is no longer returned in the response.
Below is an explanation of the timestamp formatting Akoya expects in requests, and how timestamps are returned.
Akoya follows **FDX standards** for timestamps in requests.

The `startTime` and `endTime` query parameters for the **Transactions endpoint** must follow [RFC 3339](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3339), an extension of the [ISO8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) format requiring both **date and time** in the string.
- The time must be in **UTC**.
**Data type:** `string`
**Note:** When specifying a time range, both `startTime` and `endTime` must be used.
After you submit your request:

1. Akoya converts the timestamp into whichever ISO8601 format that the **data provider** uses.
2. Akoya passes the request on to the provider.
3. The response is returned back to you **as-is**.
Providers may use any valid ISO8601 format. Your implementation should handle these differences either:

- By customizing per provider, or
- By using a robust **date/time library** in your application.

| Date        | Update                      |
|-------------|-----------------------------|
| 2024-Sep-04 | Added intro.                |
| 2024-Aug-06 | Added dev help resources.   |
| 2022-Oct-24 | Original                    |

The number of financial payments that depend on the **ACH** and **RTP** networks is growing rapidly. Traditionally, these payments require knowing and holding a customer’s account and routing numbers. The storing and transfer of this sensitive information is inherently risky and increases the likelihood of financial fraud.

One solution to decrease risk is to use **tokenized account numbers (TANs)** to replace standard account numbers. Tokenizing account numbers is a solution gaining momentum across the industry, and several Akoya data providers support TANs.

- TANs protect account numbers by replacing the actual account number with a **token**, a randomly generated number.
- The token allows you to still perform a payment **without sharing the actual account numbers**.
- The token is stored in a separate location from the actual account number and routing information, while the **token-to-account mapping** is stored in a secure vault.
**Key points:**

- Tokens have the same **form-factor** as actual account numbers.
- The **routing transit number** is different, but uses the same routing and account structure.
- The Clearing House (TCH) launched **Secure Token Exchange (STE)** to tokenize account numbers in a way that does not alter existing payment authorizations.
If there is a data breach of any participant, TANs provide these benefits:

- Mapping is separate and validated during payment processing → limits token’s value to fraudsters.
- One or many tokens can be **systematically turned off** to mitigate risk.
- Replacing tokens (if needed) is **faster and cheaper** than replacing real account numbers.
Since TANs are new, you may need to adapt systems built for standard account numbers.
👉 You can determine if an account number is tokenized by checking a **Payments API** response:
- If `paymentNetworks.identifierType = TOKENIZED_ACCOUNT_NUMBER`, then the account number is tokenized.
See: [Payments]($e/Payments/payment-networks)

Nodes.Title: Common ACH R04 Error: Account Not Found

Nodes.Text:
The **ACH R04** return code means invalid account number or account not found.  
When using TANs, this can happen if:

1. **Mismatched routing/account type**
   
   - TAN with standard routing number, or
   - Standard account number with TAN routing number.

2. **Former account numbers**
   
   - Customers may still have old standard account numbers in the system. These **cannot** replace TANs.

3. **Digit truncation**
   
   - TANs can vary by institution but are never more than **17 digits**.
   - Always start with `00`.
   - Do not drop digits (beyond the two leading zeros if needed). Dropping digits may cause an R04 error.

4. **Disabled TANs**
   
   - If a consent is revoked, the associated TAN is disabled.
   - Errors may occur if TANs are used after consent removal or expiration.
   - TANs require ongoing consent, not a one-time authorization.

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: Common ACH R04 Error: Account Not Found

Nodes.Text:

- [Reduce fraud risk with tokenized account numbers](https://akoya.com/blog/reduce-fraud-risk-with-tokenized-account-numbers)

Akoya products can be combined to help facilitate several use cases across financial services. From budgeting and investment management tools to money movement and credit enhancements, Akoya can service many of your fintech needs.
**Akoya products include:**

- Account info
- Balances
- Investments
- Payments
- Transactions
- Customers
- Statements
These products allow you to retrieve the data you need for your use case as illustrated below.
Enable instant account opening and funding without micro-deposits.
**Akoya products used:**

- Balances
- Payments
- Customers
Link an account and give consent without screen scraping.

**Akoya product used:**

- Transactions

Your goal is to **verify the account number and routing number information** that has been retrieved from the end-user.
Use the **Akoya API endpoints** to retrieve the account numbers and routing numbers of a consumer’s account directly from their financial institution’s APIs.
Matching the account numbers and routing numbers from the end-user with the numbers from the Akoya API endpoints verifies the account.
Account verification relies on the **Akoya Payments product**.
👉 For more information, see the blog post [Instant Account Verification with Akoya](https://akoya.com/blog/account-verification).
The API calls require you to have the **account holder’s consent**. Each data call requires the end-user’s associated **id token**.

- See [Get authorization code]($e/Account%20information/get-accounts-info) for the user authorization process.
- See [Token](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/get-token) to obtain the bearer token for the API calls.
The [account information endpoint]($e/Account%20information/get-accounts-info) is a standalone endpoint that supplies useful account information.
You need to retrieve a list of available accounts permissioned by the account holder from this endpoint.

**Request format:**  
GET /accounts-info/{version}/{providerId}

- `{version}`: The Akoya major version number (use `v2`).
- `{providerId}`: The shortened version of the bank data provider name (e.g., `mikomo` for Mikomo, our fictional provider).
- You can find the `providerId` for each bank listed under the **Data providers** tab of the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login).

curl --request GET \
     --url https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/accounts-info/v2/mikomo?accountIds=%3AaccountId \
     --header 'accept: application/json' \
     --header 'authorization: Bearer <id_token>'

From the results of the account information call, locate the accountId of the selected account.
This key is used for retrieving the payments credentials (account and routing numbers).
**Example account information response**

Nodes.Title: Retrieve Routing and Account Numbers from Bank

Nodes.Text:
The [payments endpoint]($e/Payments/payment-networks) supplies payment information, including the routing and account numbers.
Since this information is retrieved directly from the bank’s APIs, it qualifies as a verified account number under the Nacha WEB debit rule.
**Request format:**
GET /payments/{version}/{providerId}/{accountId}/payment-networks

- {version}: The Akoya major version number (use v2).
- {providerId}: The shortened version of the bank data provider name.
- {accountId}: Retrieved from the account information call.

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: Retrieve Routing and Account Numbers from Bank

Nodes.Text:
curl --request GET \
--url https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/payments/v2/mikomo/g833202fb0866d0ad83472c429/payment-networks \
--header 'accept: application/json' \
--header 'authorization: Bearer <id_token>'

- bankId = Routing number
- identifier = Account number
**Example payment information response**
Compare the routing and account numbers submitted by the user with the verified routing and account numbers you obtained from the Akoya endpoints.

Existing methods of account ownership validation rely on basic username and password authentication. Usernames and passwords are one of the most vulnerable areas in consumer security and subject to phishing and direct hacking attempts. Compromised credentials are the most common avenue to account takeover and fraudulent representation of account ownership.

Akoya's Customers product offers a higher level of account ownership validation. You use Akoya's API to retrieve consumer permissioned information directly from the financial institution. Data elements such as first name, last name, mailing address, e-mail address, or phone number can be used as part of a validation process. You can compare this user information retrieved from the linked external account with what you have captured directly from the end user.

The comparison process can data elements as part of a scoring algorithm comparing user-provided information with the information on file at the financial institutions. This allows data recipients to identify and flag fraud attempts during know your customer processes or whenever fraud is suspected.
For more information, see the blog post The Expansion of [Account Ownership Validation Methods](https://akoya.com/blog/account-ownership-validation-methods).
The API calls require you to have the account holder's consent. Each data call requires the end-user's associated id token.

- See [Get authorization code]($e/Account%20information/get-accounts-info) for the user authorization process
- See [Token]($e/Account%20information/get-accounts-info) to obtain the bearer token for the API calls

The [customer info endpoint]($e/Customers/customer-info) (/customers) response returns information about the end user that you can use as data points to validate account ownership. The specific end user is identified with the id_token used for the Akoya API call. The id_token is created with the authorization code generated when the user consents to sharing their data.
Make the GET request customers/{version}/{providerId}/current

- The {version} parameter is the Akoya major version number. Use v2.
- The {providerId} parameter is the shortened version of the bank data provider name, example, mikomo for Mikomo, our fictional data provider. You can find the providerId for each bank listed under the Data providers tab of the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login).

curl --request GET \
     --url https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/customers/v2/mikomo/current \
     --header 'accept: application/json'
     --header 'authorization: Bearer <id_token>'

Nodes.Title: 2. Find data elements for the validation process

Nodes.Text:
The API response contains data elements for the end user, such as first name, last name, mailing address, e-mail address, and phone number. Compare these data elements from the Akoya endpoint against the data elements submitted by the end user. Developers often implement a scoring algorithm to facilitate the comparison and flag possible fraud.
Customer info results example

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: 2. Find data elements for the validation process

Nodes.Text: Some data providers do not support the default [customer info endpoint]($e/Account%20information/get-accounts-info). Use the below procedure and the account holder information endpoint for these providers.

The [account information endpoint]($e/Customers/get-account-holder) is a standalone endpoint that supplies useful account information. You need to retrieve a list of available accounts permissioned by the account holder from this endpoint.
Make the GET request /accounts-info/{version}/{providerId}

- The {version} parameter is the Akoya major version number. Use v2.
- The {providerId} parameter is the shortened version of the bank data provider name, example, mikomo for Mikomo, our fictional data provider. You can find the providerId for each bank listed under the Data providers tab of the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login).
**Retrieve account information curl example**

curl --request GET \
 --url https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/accounts-info/v2/mikomo?accountIds=%3AaccountId \
 --header 'accept: application/json' \
 --header 'authorization: Bearer <id_token>'

From the results of the retrieve account information call, find the the accountId of the selected account. This is the key for retrieving the customer information data elements.
**Account information results example**

The account holder information endpoint (/contacts) response returns information about the end user that you can use as data points to validate account ownership. This API call uses the accountId to designate the end user. It is based on FDX 5.2.1.
Make the GET request contacts/{version}/{providerId}/{accountId}

- The {version} parameter is the Akoya major version number. Use v2.
- The {providerId} parameter is the shortened version of the bank data provider name, example, mikomo for Mikomo, our fictional data provider. You can find the providerId for each bank listed under the Data providers tab of the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login).
- You retrieved the {accountId} with the retrieve account information call.
**Retrieve account holder information example**

curl --request GET \
     --url https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/contacts/v2/mikomo/1234 \
     --header 'accept: application/json' \
     --header 'authorization: Bearer <id_token>'

Nodes.Title: Account linking and consent use case

Nodes.Text: Traditional account linking and consent flow depends on credential-based screen scraping. This process is heavily reliant on consumer credentials, which can lead to issues with data security, negative user experiences, and high website traffic. Scraped data is also less reliable and prone to errors.
Akoya offers a better solution. It provides an API-only, permissioned-driven open finance network that overcomes the inherent problems of screen scraping.

From a customer viewpoint, the process to link an account and give consent through Akoya is simple. The new app routes the user to their existing bank portal. The user completes the normal authentication process and consents to link the account.

The process for a developer begins with the consent flow. This enables a customer to authenticate, select accounts, and permission data to flow from their data provider through the Data Access Network and to a third-party fintech app. This keeps your customers' sign in credentials from being shared with third parties.

After authentication and authorization, Akoya returns the end-user to your redirect URI with an authorization grant code in the URL. This use case procedure began after you receive that authorization grant code.
For more information, see the blog post [A Consumer-First Approach to Account Linking](https://akoya.com/blog/account-linking).

The API calls require you to have joined the Data Recipient Hub and set up your app to work with the Akoya Data Access Network (DAN). For more information on these processes, refer to these resources:

- [Onboarding: Getting started](page:getting-started/introduction)
- [How to work with Akoya](page:guides/preparing-to-integrate)

Akoya returns the end-user to your redirect URI with an authorization grant code in the URL. code= precedes the grant code. The code fogeqqbz2xi23hvgvlu4ka2kq is shown in the example. For more information, see Get authorization code.
https://example-app.com/callback?code=fogeqqbz2xi23hvgvlu4ka2kq&state=123abc

Nodes.Title: Exchange the code for an ID and refresh token

Nodes.Text: The token endpoint response returns an id_token and a refresh_token. The id_token is the bearer token used for data calls. Use the refresh_token retrieves a new set of tokens. For more information, see Tokens.
Make the GET request /token for an id token.

- Set the grant_type to authorization_code.
- The redirect_uri is the URI where user will be redirected after end-users authorization is complete.
- The code is the authorization grant code retrieved in step 1.

Nodes.Title: Exchange code for tokens curl example

Nodes.Text:
curl --request POST
--url https://sandbox-idp.ddp.akoya.com/token
--header 'accept: application/json'
--header 'content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded'
--data grant_type=authorization_code
--data redirect_uri=https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/flow/callback
--data 'code=<authorization-code>'

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: Exchange code for tokens curl example
Exchange the code for an ID and refresh token

Nodes.Title: Find and copy the token strings

Nodes.Text: The API response contains the id_token and refresh_token strings. Copy and store these values in a safe place. Use your current secure token storage or implement a way to store each end-user's unique tokens.

{
"expires_in": 86399,
"id_token": "<id-token>",
"refresh_token": "<refresh-token",
"scope": "openid offline_access",
"token_type": "bearer"
}

Nodes.SuggestedLinkText: Find and copy the token strings

Nodes.Text: Repeat your get request on the token endpoint with different parameters to obtain a new set of tokens. The refresh token expiration is set by the data provider.
Make the GET request /token to refresh tokens.

- Set the grant_type to refresh_token.
- The refresh_token is in the results from the tokens call in step 1.
- The client_id is your app's client ID from Akoya
- The client_secret is your app's client secret from Akoya
You can find the client_id and client_secret under the My app tab of the [Akoya Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login).

curl --request POST 
--url https://sandbox-idp.ddp.akoya.com/token 
--header 'accept: application/json' 
--header 'content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' 
--data grant_type=refresh_token 
--data 'refresh_token=<refresh-token>' 
--data 'client_id=<client-id>' 
--data 'client_secret=<client-secret>'
The refresh tokens result is the same format as the token results example.

Users often have multiple accounts across different financial institutions. Personal Financial Management (PFM) solutions must consolidate this information into one place to provide an accurate view of a consumer’s financial condition.
The aggregation service must securely consolidate and provide real-time access to all relevant financial data while maintaining **privacy** and **consent**.

You can achieve this by integrating the **Akoya API** into your solution. The [Akoya Investments](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/investments) (or [Balances](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/balances)) and [Transactions]($e/Transactions/get-transactions) products let data recipients and users view and manage their money in a consolidated manner.
These products access financial account data from multiple institutions and present the collated details to the user.
For more information, see the blog post: [The Expansion of Account Ownership Validation Methods](https://akoya.com/blog/account-ownership-validation-methods).

- The API calls require the **account holder’s consent**.
- Each data call requires the **end-user’s associated id token**.
🔗 See:

- [Get authorization code]($e/Account%20information/get-accounts-info) for the user authorization process
- [Token]($e/Account%20information/get-accounts-info) to obtain the bearer token for the API calls

The **Investments product**’s `/accounts` endpoint is standalone.  
It supplies:

- Balance data
- Extended investment details
- Basic account information
**GET** `/accounts/{version}/{providerId}`

- `{version}` = Akoya major version (use **v2**)
- `{providerId}` = shortened version of bank provider name (e.g., `mikomo` for fictional provider Mikomo)
👉 You can find `providerId` values in the **Data providers tab** of the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login).

curl --request GET \
     --url https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/accounts/v2/mikomo \
     --header 'accept: application/json' \
     --header 'authorization: Bearer <id_token>'
From the investments response, gather:

- accountIds of permissioned accounts
- Associated holdings and balances

{
    "accountId": "426444887",
    "accountType": "IRA",
    "accountNumberDisplay": "*****5071",
    "currency": { "currencyCode": "USD" },
    "description": "Rollover IRA",
    "nickname": "My IRA",
    "productName": "RolloverIRA Investment Acct",
    "status": "OPEN",
    "balanceType": "ASSET",
    "availableCashBalance": 69746.83,
    "balanceAsOf": "2022-04-08T08:46:14",
    "balanceList": [
        {
            "balanceDate": "2022-04-07T00:00:00",
            "balanceName": "Minimumequitycall",
            "balanceType": "AMOUNT",
            "balanceValue": 0,
            "currency": { "currencyCode": "USD" }
        }
    ]
}

The Transactions product retrieves up to two years of transaction history for an account.
It requires the accountId retrieved earlier.
GET /transactions/{version}/{providerId}/{accountId}

- {version} = v2
- {providerId} = bank provider ID
- {accountId} = retrieved account ID

**Example (Retrieve Transactions - cURL)**
This retrieves the first 50 transactions (default offset = 0, limit = 50).

curl --request GET \
     --url 'https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/transactions/v2/mikomo/5242702?offset=0&limit=50' \
     --header 'accept: application/json' \
     --header 'authorization: Bearer <id_token>'
**Example Response (Transactions Without Paging)**
Transactions often exceed the default 50 transaction limit.

Pagination links at the top of the results reference additional records.
Pagination uses offset, limit, and time parameters.

Use these links to make further calls and retrieve all data needed.
For details, see [Transactions Pagination](page:guides/pagination).
You must repeat the steps for:

- Each financial institution (providerId)
- Each account at those institutions (accountId)

Nodes.Title: Get-Accounts-Info
Nodes.Name: get_accounts_info
Nodes.Description:
Get basic account information including accountId, masked account number, type, description, etc.

To view the response schema, select the `200` response below. Then pick an option for annuity, deposit, insurance, investment, loan, and line of credit account types. 

For an example payload response, see the `200` example response below the `Try it` feature. The example is from a deposit account but all account types are supported by this endpoint.

> 🛑
> 
> The *id_token* should be used as the bearer token with this call.

Use the `mode` query param to receive FDX-aligned, standardized data values (Beta). For example:

`https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/accounts-info/v2/mikomo?mode=standard`

`mode` is available in both sandbox and production.

`mode` is supported by a subset of providers. Log into the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login) and click [here](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/support/article/kA0Uw00000015GzKAI) to view a list of all providers supporting the `mode` parameter.

Nodes.Title: Customer-Info
Nodes.Name: customer_info
Nodes.Description:
This product supports use cases such as payment enablement, account opening, and identity verification. Responses return information about the authorized end-user, the customer associated with the `id_token` used in the call. This information may include, but is not limited to, the customer identifier, name, email, address, and phone number.
To see the response schema, select the `200` response below. For an example payload response, see the `200` example response below the *Try it* feature. This product requires consumer consent to share all account holder information. > 🛑 The `id_token` should be used as the bearer token with this call. >

Nodes.Title: Get-Account-Holder
Nodes.Name: get_account_holder
Nodes.Description:
This product supports use cases such as payment enablement, account opening, identity verification,or lending & credit enhancement. Responses return information about the authorized consumer, the customer associated with the `id_token` used in the call, and the relationship specific to the provided `accountId`.

> 📌 Please note!
>
> This endpoint provides additional information which may not be required for your use case, making it inefficient compared to the [/customer info](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/customer-info) endpoint. Please refer to to the [Customers guide](https://docs.akoya.com/reference/customers) for more information about this endpoint.

Get account holder information. Based on FDX 5.2.1.

This product requires consumer consent to share all account holder information.

> 🛑 The `id_token` should be used as the bearer token with this call.
>

Nodes.Text: Investments
An instance of the `InvestmentsApi` class can be accessed from the API Client.
investments_api = client.investments

Nodes.Title: Get-Accounts
Nodes.Name: get_accounts
Nodes.Description:
Get detailed account information that includes Akoya products Account Info and Balances for all account types (annunity, deposit, insurance, investments, line of credit, and loan) and adds the Investments product to investment accounts including contributions, holdings, vesting information, and more.

To view the response schema, select the `200` response below. Then pick an option for annuity, deposit, insurance, investment, loan, and line of credit account types. 

For an example payload response, see the `200` example response below the `Try it` feature. The example is from an investment account but all account types are supported and returned by this endpoint.

> 🛑
> 
> The *id_token* should be used as the bearer token with this call.

Use the `mode` query param to receive FDX-aligned, standardized data values (Beta). For example:

`https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/accounts/v2/mikomo?mode=standard`

`mode` is available in both sandbox and production.

`mode` is supported by a subset of providers. Log into the [Data Recipient Hub](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/login) and click [here](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/support/article/kA0Uw00000015GzKAI) to view a list of all providers supporting the `mode` parameter.

Nodes.Title: Get-Statement-List
Nodes.Name: get_statement_list
Nodes.Description:
Retrieve a list of available statements for the end-user's consented accounts. You may request a date range of up to two years of historical statements (maximum date ranges vary by provider).

The paginated response includes an array of statement information with the end-user's account id and statement details such as statement id, date, description, and status. The results also include links to GET the statement image.

Nodes.Title: Get-Statements
Nodes.Name: get_statements
Nodes.Description:
Retrieve a specific account statement file. Use [HTTP Accept request-header](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html) to specify desired content types. 

For the initial launch, only PDF statements are supported. PDFs are returned in the response.

### cURL request

We recommend using the auto-generated cURL request with the {idToken}, accountId, providerId, statementId, and version with an added cURL parameter to return the output to a file. For example:

```curl
curl --request GET --url https://sandbox-products.ddp.akoya.com/statements/v2/mikomo/513815781465/P9CvLPKDaFRMbNDkhu1 --header "accept: application/pdf" --header "authorization: Bearer {idtoken}" --output example.pdf
```
Nodes.ResponseText: This method returns an [```ApiResponse```]($h/__additional_documentation/Utilities/ApiResponse) instance. The `body` property of this instance returns the response data which is of type ```Any```.

                  account_id,

                  x_akoya_interaction_type=None)

Allowed values are `user` or `batch`. 
`user` indicates a request is prompted by an end-user action.
`batch` indicates the request is part of a batch process.

Nodes.Title: Get Tax Form
Nodes.Name: get_tax_form
Nodes.Description:
Get the Tax Statement as JSON or PDF for a single tax document for the customer. Use [HTTP Accept request-header](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html) to specify desired content types. See `AcceptHeader` definition for typical values.

Not all providers support PDF payloads. See [this article](https://recipient.ddp.akoya.com/support/article/kA0Uw00000026VxKAI) in the Data Recipent Hub for a list of providers that support document PDFs.
Nodes.ResponseText: This method returns an [```ApiResponse```]($h/__additional_documentation/Utilities/ApiResponse) instance. The `body` property of this instance returns the response data which is of type [```TaxStatement1```]($m/Tax%20Statement1).
